title: King walk
text:
In <a href="chess">chess</a>, a king walk, also known as a king march, steel king (, literally "wanderking") or fighting king, refers to occasions where the <a href="king%20%28chess%29">king</a> travels up the <a href="chessboard">board</a> in the <a href="middle%20game">middle game</a> or <a href="Chess%20opening">opening</a>, often involved in a against the opposing king. This is a highly unusual occurrence, since the safety of the king is considered paramount, and players are recommended to keep the king out of harm's way, at least until the <a href="Chess%20endgame">endgame</a>. In contrast, <a href="Wilhelm%20Steinitz">Wilhelm Steinitz</a>, often known as the father of modern chess, was renowned for his <a href="Maxim%20%28saying%29">maxim</a> that "the king is a fighting piece". Dutch chess <a href="historian">historian</a> and <a href="author">author</a> <a href="Tim%20Krabb%C3%A9">Tim Krabbé</a> has documented over one hundred such games.
Because of the rarity of such <a href="chess%20tactics">tactics</a>, those which reap rewards for the attacking player often have bestowed upon them. Perhaps the most famous in recent history, where <a href="Nigel%20Short">Nigel Short</a> defeated <a href="Jan%20Timman">Jan Timman</a> in <a href="Tilburg">Tilburg</a> in 1991, was voted as one of the hundred greatest chess games in a list compiled by <a href="FIDE%20Master">FM</a> <a href="Graham%20Burgess">Graham Burgess</a>, and <a href="Grandmaster%20%28chess%29">GM</a>s <a href="John%20Nunn">John Nunn</a> and <a href="John%20Emms%20%28chess%20player%29">John Emms</a>.
A can also refer to occasions where the king travels across the board (from to , or vice versa) to reach a safer position.
